title: MSW Program Virtual Current Student Panel
description:
Discover What’s Possible in Our MSW Program Our  MSW program  prepares leaders in social work to help children, youth and families in a diverse local and global society. The program aims to prepare advanced practitioners to provide a range of clinical and advocacy services to vulnerable children, adolescents and their families. We're hosting a   virtual current student panel November 5 at 7:00 PM (EST) . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. title: Weekly Wednesday Zoom Check-ins @ 8pm
description:
Weekly meetings Description @ 8pm on Wednesdays 
 Welcome to the  ​ Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring   (DREAM)  Group for College Students with  Disabilities and Allies!  We invite and welcome you, (undergraduates, grad students and allies) to a supportive discussion with peers. Whether you would like to just come hang out with us, meet each other, talk about your experiences as students, vent about life or chill and laugh, we can do it all! We can provide each other with community care!  
 If you are coming as an Ally here are a few ways to be an ally to the disabled community: 1) Check your own internalized ableism. 2) Understand that not every disability is visible to you. 3) If you notice inaccessibility, speak up! Advocate for us. 4) Attend events that center disabled voices. 5) If a person in your life has a disability, take the time to learn about it. 6) Make mistakes, apologize, and learn from them. 7) Consume some media (made by disabled people) about disability. 
 Meetings will be held online via Zoom

title: "Which Animals Are Conscious?" - Philosophy for Lunch
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
• Title: “Which Animals Are Conscious?” — Philosophy for Lunch 
 • November 6, 2024 
 • Time: 12:00–1:00PM 
 • Location: The Cohen Lounge in Dickson Hall (Room 178) 
   
 Description: 
 Animal consciousness is a hot topic among philosophers, neuroscientists, and psychologists these days. An animal is  conscious  whenever there is something it feels like to be that animal. Today, most believe that at least some nonhuman animals are conscious. For example, most think there is something it’s like to be a cat. Cats presumably have experiences associated with sight, hearing, and smell. It also seems likely that they feel pain and experience pleasure. However, things become less clear and more controversial when it comes to animals outside of the class of mammals. Over lunch, we will explore which other animals have experiences, whether there are nonconscious animals, and how it might be possible for us to know. 
   
 • What is P4L? Students, professors, and other philosophy enthusiasts close-read and discuss a few great passages of philosophy. 
   
 • Who’s invited? No preparation or previous knowledge of philosophy is needed. Everyone is welcome! 
   
 • Should I bring anything? Bring a beverage, and if you're hungry, bring your actual lunch.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: RULE OF LAW AND THE CORE AMERICAN INSTITUTIONS
description:
The Declaration of Independence lays out a legalistic argument for separation from Great Britain. With this start, the founders placed the primacy of law as bedrock principle of a new nation. Many of the features ultimately enshrined in the Constitution rest upon this base including separation of powers, checks and balances, judicial independence, federalism and state’s rights. Our system of market capitalism stems from the same starting point with an emphasis on property rights, contract and state enforcement. 
 Join President Koppell for a lecture and discussion tracing rule of law as a through-line of American democracy that predates the founding of the United States and has served as the logic model for the conflicts and controversies that have shaped the American experiment. 
 Event is open to all

 Bring your pre-loved items to trade or browse and see what catches your eye. It’s a great way to refresh your wardrobe, find a new favorite book, or stock up on art supplies without spending a dime. Enjoy a fun, friendly atmosphere, meet new people and give old items a new life. 
 Let’s come together to create a more sustainable community. We can't wait to see you there! ♻️✨ 
 PS:  The amount of materials we offer depends on the donations we receive. If there aren’t many donations, there may not be as many clothes available, so feel free to bring what you can! While bringing clothes is appreciated, it’s not a requirement. Your contributions help make the event even better.

title: Real Talk: Love, Friendship & Boundaries
description: This interactive workshop, hosted by Health Promotion, will focus on building and maintaining healthy connections in friendships, dating, and intimate relationships. Participants will explore expectations within different types of relationships, learn how to set and respect boundaries, and identify key characteristics of healthy partnerships such as trust, respect, communication, and equality. Through engaging discussion and activities, students will leave with tools to strengthen their personal relationships and recognize red flags in unhealthy dynamics. This program encourages reflection and empowers students to make informed, positive choices in their interactions with others.

 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: Walk With FoMSF – Miles for Medicine
description:
Join us for a fun, relaxing, and meaningful Walkathon to promote wellness, community, and school spirit — all while making a difference! Lace up your sneakers and walk (or run!) alongside friends, faculty, and members of the MSU Run for Fun Club. 
 This year, we’re fundraising to support Doctors Without Borders in bringing humanitarian relief to Gaza. Together, we can make every step count toward hope and healing. 
 While you’re there, enjoy our Bake Sale featuring delicious homemade treats - all proceeds will go toward this important cause. 
 We’ll also have a Vitals Information Booth, where two EMTs will be available to take vitals and share helpful health and wellness tips. Plus, check out our informative posters, music, and chill vibes throughout the event. 
 A donation jar will also be available for anyone who’d like to contribute further to the relief efforts. 
 Come out, have fun, and walk for a purpose , every step and every cookie helps! 🌍💚

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Viola Masterclass with Lawrence Dutton of the Emerson String Quartet
description:
Viola Masterclass with Lawrence Dutton 
 Grammy-winning violist  Lawrence Dutton  of the  Emerson String Quartet  will lead a masterclass on chamber music artistry, ensemble collaboration, and expressive string interpretation. 
 Bio: 
 Lawrence Dutton  is the violist of the 9-time Grammy-winning  Emerson String Quartet,  with over 50 recordings and collaborations with artists such as  Isaac Stern, Renée Fleming,  Sir Paul McCartney,  and  Joshua Bell.  He has performed with leading string quartets and piano trios, appeared as soloist with major U.S. and European orchestras, and been featured at top festivals including A spen, Ravinia, Santa Fe,  and  Music@Menlo . 
 Since 2001, he has served as Artistic Director of the  Hoch Chamber Music Series.  He is Distinguished Professor of Viola and Chamber Music at Stony Brook University and Distinguished Artist at the Robert McDuffie Center for Strings at Mercer University. A Juilliard graduate, he holds multiple honorary doctorates and, with the Emerson Quartet, has received the  Avery Fisher Award, Chamber Music America’s National Service Award,  and induction into the  American Classical Music Hall of Fame.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Immersive Residency with Mezzo-soprano  Isabel Leonard and University Symphony Orchestra
description:
Join us for the  fifth annual  reimagined professional residency program at the John J. Cali School of Music, where week-long residencies with top artists and ensembles offer students immersive opportunities to collaborate, learn, and explore the evolving, often nontraditional landscape of music today. 
 Three-time Grammy Award-winning mezzo-soprano  Isabel Leonard  joins the Cali School of Music for a multi-day residency featuring masterclasses, workshops, and a performance with the  University Symphony Orchestra . On campus, Leonard will work with undergraduate and graduate students on acting for singers, artist–manager collaboration, and opera interpretation. Renowned for her expressive artistry and commanding stage presence, she continues to perform leading roles with major opera houses worldwide, including Carmen and Frida at  The Metropolitan Opera,  Angelina at  Bayerische Staatsoper,  and  L’enfant et les sortilèges  with the  San Diego Symphony.  Leonard also serves as a Perspectives Artist at  Carnegie Hall  and appears with the  New York Philharmonic  and international recital stages this season. 
 Performance of  Knoxville: Summer of 1915  with University Symphony Orchestra,  Kyle Ritenauer,  conductor 
 Followed by a vocal masterclass with Cali voice students. 
 FREE TICKETS:  https://bit.ly/CaliLeonardConcert

title: Montclair Unraveled General Body Meeting!!!
description:
Do you want to learn a new knitting or crochet pattern? Do you want to make a cool craft but can't pick one or figure out where to start? Then come to the Montclair Unraveled!

All are welcome, whether you have the most craft experience possible or none at all. Come by and enjoy the company of others who share your passions for the fiber arts!

title: DREAM MONTHLY: From Disability Rights to Disability Justice
description:
November Pause for Change continues to discuss the evolution from Disability rights to DISABILITY JUSTICE! We will also explore the working definition of ableism. The discussion will highlight the differences between Disability Justice and Disability Rights, delving into the broader framework of the Disability Justice movement. We will also examine the key principles that drive this movement. As a creative and reflective exercise, each participant will receive a page from the Sins Invalid coloring book to personalize with their initials or designs, providing a meaningful way to engage with the concepts discussed. This meeting is an opportunity to deepen our understanding of Disability Justice and its impact on advocacy and inclusivity. 
 Welcome to the  ​Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring (DREAM)  Group for College Students with Disabilities and Allies! We invite and welcome you! Monthly Monday Meetings will be held on Mondays of each month! Put in your Calendar in advance, as a reminder! This is an in person event & online, MASKS are HIGHLY ENCOURAGED and will be provided. 
 If you cant make in-person - no worries - join us online! https://montclair.zoom.us/j/92835077081?pwd=wbXrCoUk5daw91yU3NAwY3aEXaGkbj.1

title: Dabkeh Class
description:
Join us for an exciting Dabkeh Class hosted by the Arab Student Association (ASA) in collaboration with the Arabic Program! Dabkeh is a traditional Arab dance that celebrates unity, rhythm, and cultural pride through synchronized steps and lively music. 
 This session will be taught by our talented Event Coordinator, Tanya Abu Kamal, and Social Media Manager, Lila Baladi, who will guide you through the basics and teach you how to move with the rhythm like a pro! Whether you’re new to Dabkeh or already know a few steps, everyone is welcome to join in, dance, and have fun.

title: Fall of the Berlin Wall - History Club Crisis Sim and GBM
organization: The Historical Society at Montclair State
description:
Step into one of the most pivotal moments of the Cold War with the History Club! Through a mix of roleplaying, interactive activities, and a short history lesson, you’ll get the chance to experience how key figures shaped global events and influenced the world we live in today. 
 No background knowledge is required! This is a fun and engaging way to dive into history, think critically about big decisions, and explore the human side of world-changing moments. 
 All students are welcome to join, and free pizza will be available to everyone who stops by!

title: Lila fi Shamal Ifriqiya
location: Student Center 250ABC - Ballrooms A, B, and C
description: Step into the ballroom and step out of Montclair. For one night only, the walls will come alive with the sights, sounds, and flavors of North Africa. Wander through a celebration of the region’s rich traditions, taste dishes that carry the soul of the Maghreb and beyond, hear music that moves across deserts and cities alike, and feel the warmth of community that ties it all together. Expect food, culture, and stories that make you feel like you’ve traveled across the Mediterranean without ever leaving campus. North Africa is coming to you. Don’t miss it!

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: SA Awareness & Prevention with the Sisters of  Phi Sigma Sigma & Theta Phi Alpha
location: University Hall 1070 - Phyllis & Gerald LeBoff Lecture Hall
description:
Join the sisters of Phi Sigma Sigma and Theta Phi Alpha for an important evening focused on sexual assault awareness, prevention, and empowerment. This collaborative event is dedicated to fostering a safe, supportive, and informed campus community. 
 Through educational resources and guest speakers. Attendees will gain valuable insights into consent, bystander intervention, and how to support survivors. Our goal is to create a space for open dialogue, learning, and collective action against sexual violence. 
 Whether you're seeking knowledge, resources, or ways to get involved, this event welcomes all students to be part of the conversation and the movement toward a safer community!

title: Food Recovery Network General Body Meeting
description:
We’re thrilled to invite you to our General Body Meetings! This is a fantastic opportunity to get involved, meet fellow members, and learn about the exciting plans and initiatives we have in store. 
 - Get to know the team, hear about our mission, and understand the goals and vision for this year. We’ll also introduce key members and roles within the organization. 
 - Learn about upcoming events, projects, and opportunities for involvement. We'll outline our plans and how you can contribute to our success. 
 - Connect with other members, make new friends, and build relationships within our community.  
 - Find out how you can volunteer, join committees, or participate in special projects. We’ll provide information on various roles and how you can make an impact. 
 Whether you’re a new member or a returning one, your presence and participation will help shape the future of our organization.  
 We look forward to meeting you and embarking on this exciting journey together!

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Information Session- Wednesday, November 12, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
   
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: Spilling SustainabiliTEA
description:
Join us for a thoughtful evening of tea, pizza, conversation, and connection as we explore how federal policies shape sustainability from the environment, to the economy, to our everyday lives. 
 This “Tea & Talk” will unpack how changes in clean air and water protections, healthcare access, and immigration enforcement ripple through communities, influencing both social equity and environmental well-being. Together, we’ll also take a closer look at the lasting social impacts of systemic inequality and redlining, and how they continue to affect health, housing, and trust in public institutions today. 
 Come ready, spilling some sustainabiliTEA to share your thoughts, listen to others, and imagine what true sustainability can look like in our communities.  
 All are welcome!

 Welcome to the  ​ Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring   (DREAM)  Group for College Students with  Disabilities and Allies!  We invite and welcome you, (undergraduates, grad students and allies) to a supportive discussion with peers. Whether you would like to just come hang out with us, meet each other, talk about your experiences as students, vent about life or chill and laugh, we can do it all! We can provide each other with community care!  
 If you are coming as an Ally here are a few ways to be an ally to the disabled community: 1) Check your own internalized ableism. 2) Understand that not every disability is visible to you. 3) If you notice inaccessibility, speak up! Advocate for us. 4) Attend events that center disabled voices. 5) If a person in your life has a disability, take the time to learn about it. 6) Make mistakes, apologize, and learn from them. 7) Consume some media (made by disabled people) about disability. 
 Meetings will be held online via Zoom

description:

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Bloomfield Pop-Up Pantry
description:
Pop-Up Pantry @ Bloomfield College! 
 The Pop-up Pantry at Bloomfield college will provide free food and essential personal care items to students. Stop by to pick up fresh produce, canned items, household supplies, milk, deli meat, frozen meals, cereal, feminine hygiene products, toiletries and much more, all at no cost! Our goal is to ensure everyone in our community has access to nutritious food and everyday essentials. 
   
 Visiting the Pop-Up Pantry: 
 1) Please have your Event Pass, CWID and have a  PantrySoft Registration .  2) Please bring your own shopping bag and ID card! 
 ***Visitors are welcome to visit the Red Hawk Pantry once per week, including visits to the Montclair Pantry.*** 
 Our Mission:   
 We aim to address food insecurity across Montclair State University. The Red Hawk Pantry is open to all students, staff, and faculty at no cost. If you are unable to visit during our regular hours, please reach out via email at redhawkpantry@montclair.edu  
 Stay updated by following us on Instagram: @montclair_redhawkpantry 
 Date and Time: Thursday, November 13th 2025, 4PM to 6PM 
   
 Co-sponsored by: Wellness Center at Bloomfield College, Campus Activities at Bloomfield College

title: Clinical Psychology (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Transform Lives With A  Career In Clinical Psychology 
 Montclair's Clinical Psychology program combines advanced education with practical experience. Whether you’re interested in working in private practice or research, we’ll walk you through the wide range of career paths available for clinical psychology graduates. We offer two  STEM-Designated  concentrations within our rigorous Master's program, tailored to your unique practice objectives: 
 
 Clinical Psychology, Child/Adolescent Psychology Concentration (MA) Students in the child/adolescent concentration learn about the unique psychological needs of children and adolescents, as well as developmental considerations in psychopathology, assessment, and treatment, including the role of family and social contexts. This concentration is designed to prepare students for MA-level clinical positions in mental health settings, particularly those that serve children and families.    
 Clinical Psychology, Forensic Psychology Concentration (MA) The Forensic Psychology concentration is designed to prepare students to offer master’s level clinical services to legal system-involved populations in settings that do not require licensure. Such settings include mental health and drug court settings, offender rehabilitation programs, child and family advocacy settings and bona fide public service agencies exempted by state boards of psychological examiners for non-doctoral providers. 
 
 Ready to learn more? Join us for a  virtual information session on November 13 at 5:30 PM (EST)  to explore Montclair's programs in Clinical Psychology and speak directly with our faculty.

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Multi-Woodwind Masterclass with Brandon Wright
description:
Multi-Woodwind Masterclass with Brandon Wright 
 Brandon Wright  is a New York based saxophonist, multi-instrumentalist, and award-winning composer originally from Woodcliff Lake, New Jersey. 
 Known for his versatility, Brandon has performed with a wide range of iconic artists including  Smokey Robinson, Nile Rodgers & CHIC, Dr. John, Blood, Sweat & Tears, Doc Severinsen,  Max Weinberg, The Mingus Big Band,   and  Chuck Mangione.  He has recorded two critically acclaimed albums,  Boiling Point  and  Journeyman   (Posi-Tone Records) and currently holds the Reed 1 chair in the hit Broadway production  MJ: The Musical .

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester we will be focusing on the theme: "The Fruits of the Spirit". We pray that our students will learn about the Fruits of the Spirit in the Bible and be able to bear good fruit in their walk with God.  
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: Information Session: Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group
description:
Are you a graduate student working on a journal article for publication? Learn more about the Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group! This writing group will run over 13 weeks during the Spring semester (January 26 - April 24, 2026), with a week off in March. Weekly topics will include: publication venues, selecting a journal, writing your argument, literature review, citation management and more. We will use Wendy Laura Belcher’s  Writing  Your Journal Article in Twelve Weeks  to guide the discussions and work. Register to attend this Zoom information session where we will discuss how the program will run, the expected time commitment, and answer any other questions you may have. Please contact our Graduate Assistant, Emily Cepin, at  cepine1@montclair.edu  with any questions. A limited number of seats are available. If you would like to register for the club without attending an info session, you may do so by completing this  registration form . Sponsored by the Center for Writing Excellence and the University Libraries. 
 Register Here: https://montclair.libcal.com/event/14826409

title: Free Swim Clinic - Turns
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Do you have a specific skill you really want to work on but never had the chance to, or that you have been meaning to learn? Each clinic will have its own topic to work on and really be able to go in-depth on. Skills include treading, flip turns, sprints, starts, and more. 
 Clinic Focus Dates

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Trumpet Masterclass with Dr. Javian Brabham
description:
Join us for a brass masterclass with  Dr. Javian Brabham ,  Director of Brass Studies at New York University. 
 Dr. Javian Brabham  is Assistant Professor of Music and Music Education and Director of Brass Studies at New York University. Previously, he taught at Valdosta State University and Young Harris College. A South Carolina native and graduate of the SC Governor’s School for the Arts and Humanities, he earned degrees from Florida State University and the University of New Mexico. 
 An active performer, he is Principal Trumpet of the Albany (GA) Symphony Orchestra and has appeared with the American Composers Orchestra, New York Pops, Boise Philharmonic, and Gateways Music Festival Orchestra. He has presented masterclasses nationwide and performed at major national and international conferences. 
 A founding member of the Brookwood Trio, he has toured regionally and appeared at international festivals. His students have been accepted to top programs, earned ITG scholarships, and been finalists at the National Trumpet Competition. He is an active member of the International Trumpet Guild, NAfME, CMS, NACWPI, and NTC.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: RA+P and Residence Life Coffee House Night
description:
Coffeehouse is our live music event where students can sign up to perform in Russ Lounge. Whether you’re playing, singing, or just coming to hang out, it’s always a great night of creativity and community. 
   
 The goal of the event is to turn Russ Lounge into a performance space that can accommodate an audience, but it’s also a hands-on opportunity to learn how to set up a performance from start to finish. We will be mixing on a Midas M32R, so it's also an opportunity to learn how digital mixers for live audio work. All that prep work culminates in a show featuring Montclair State students from 7 PM to 9:15 PM. We go through the process of setup, performance, and breakdown. IF this interests you, please fill out  t his form  for more information on how to join the crew. 
   
 For those interested in performing in the upcoming coffeehouse, we implore you to fill out  this google form , all applicants will receive an email  with the setlist once all responses have been sent out! 
   
 See you soon, stay groovy!! 
   
 All students are welcome, commuters need to be signed in a with a resident following Residence Life guest registration procedures.

title: Information Session- Monday, November 17, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
   
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: WMSC Unplugged: Live in the Gallery
description:
WMSC Unplugged  is excited to be back in the Segal Gallery with a special live performance by Malachi Nassér, a local New Jersey musician, composer, producer, and multi-instrumentalist. Nassér's music is rooted in soulful R&B with rock influences. Nassér is a noted humanitarian and philanthropist, garnering two congressional citations and a Joint Legislative Resolution from the New Jersey Senate and General Assembly, as well as the recipient of the 2015 NAACP Youth Award. This performance is situated in the exhibition  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia , which reimagines the future of space travel through Black potentiality. 
 Doors open at 5:30 pm.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Information Session- Wednesday, November 19, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
   
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: Information Session: Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group
description:
Are you a graduate student working on a journal article for publication? Learn more about the Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group! This writing group will run over 13 weeks during the Spring semester (January 26 - April 24, 2026), with a week off in March. Weekly topics will include: publication venues, selecting a journal, writing your argument, literature review, citation management and more. We will use Wendy Laura Belcher’s  Writing  Your Journal Article in Twelve Weeks  to guide the discussions and work. Register to attend this Zoom information session where we will discuss how the program will run, the expected time commitment, and answer any other questions you may have. title: Weekly Wednesday Zoom Check-ins @ 8pm
description:
Weekly meetings Description @ 8pm on Wednesdays 
 Welcome to the  ​ Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring   (DREAM)  Group for College Students with  Disabilities and Allies!  We invite and welcome you, (undergraduates, grad students and allies) to a supportive discussion with peers. Whether you would like to just come hang out with us, meet each other, talk about your experiences as students, vent about life or chill and laugh, we can do it all! We can provide each other with community care!  
 If you are coming as an Ally here are a few ways to be an ally to the disabled community: 1) Check your own internalized ableism. 2) Understand that not every disability is visible to you. 3) If you notice inaccessibility, speak up! Advocate for us. 4) Attend events that center disabled voices. 5) If a person in your life has a disability, take the time to learn about it. 6) Make mistakes, apologize, and learn from them. 7) Consume some media (made by disabled people) about disability. 
 Meetings will be held online via Zoom

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: 2026 Class Gift Tabling - Information and Philanthropy Cord Pick-Up
description:
Each year, our graduating class participates in a proud Class Gift tradition where members of the class invest in the University by supporting areas of Montclair State University that are most important to them. We invite the Class of 2026 to come together to show your support! 
 All gifts to Montclair count! Make your gift to any area of campus you feel most passionate about – such as the Emergency Book Fund, The Red Hawk Pantry, your school or college, The Fund for Montclair State or athletic program. 
 Your gift will pay it forward for future Red Hawks and kick-start your philanthropic connection to Montclair. 
 
 Commemorate your class year! Make a gift of at least  $20.26  and you’ll receive your customized philanthropy cord to wear over your commencement robe.  
 For a gift of  $40 , celebrate this milestone with your family, friends and colleagues by having your message displayed on the screen at the Commencement you will be participating in, and receive a customized philanthropy cord. 
 
 How do I get my customized philanthropy cord? 
 Customized philanthropy cords will be available for pick-up: 
 
 Tuesday, October 28 from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Thursday, November 20  from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Tuesday, December 2 from 12:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Bloomfield Campus Graduation Fair: Wednesday, December 10th from 12:00 – 6:00 p.m. in Deacon’s Den, Talbott Hall  (for Bloomfield graduates only) 
 Montclair Campus Graduation Fairs: Thursday, December 11th from 10:00 a.m. – 7:00 p.m. in the Student Center Ballrooms  (for Montclair or Bloomfield graduates) 
 
 Graduates can also arrange to pick up their philanthropy cords in the Overlook Corporate Center, 150 Clove Road, Little Falls, NJ during business hours, Monday through Friday, 8:30 a.m. – 4:30 p.m. Philanthropy cords can also be mailed to those who cannot pick it up. The last day we will mail the cords is Monday, December 22, 2025 at 2:30 p.m. Please contact James Stewart, Associate Director of Annual Giving at stewartj@montclair.edu or 973-655-5328 to finalize options to get your cords for the Winter Commencement. 
 Every student has benefitted from donor generosity to areas of academic support, emergency funding for students and overall priorities to boost students’ success every day. Thank you for paying it forward! For more information, please contact James Stewart, Associate Director of Annual Giving, at 973-655-5328 or stewartj@montclair.edu.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester we will be focusing on the theme: "The Fruits of the Spirit". We pray that our students will learn about the Fruits of the Spirit in the Bible and be able to bear good fruit in their walk with God.  
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Turtleback Zoo
description:
Join your friends for a day at the Zoo! See animals from all over the world as you enjoy lunch at your choice of cafes around the park. Bring cash for lunch, a water bottle to stay hydrated, and comfortable walking shoes. 
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register online through  Fusion , in the Student Recreation Center’s main office, or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Registration opens October 20th 
 Cost for Students $10 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Saturday, November 22, 2025 
 10:00 am – 4:00 pm 
 Begins at Student Recreation Center 
 
 What to bring:  Water, lunch, long pants, sneakers, and sunscreen. Participants MUST wear sneakers in order to go on the zipline and obstacle course. 
 Note:  Tree Top Adventures restricts obstacle course and zipline participants to a strict weight limit of 250 lbs. Students may opt to participate in only the Zoo portion of the trip should they like. 
 Potential Hazards:  Unpredictable weather changes, sunburn/heat exhaustion, dehydration, allergic reactions/poisonous plants, insect bites and injury by running, including sprains, lacerations, abrasions and fractures.

title: Swipe Out Hunger
description:
As part of Montclair State University’s continuous commitment to eliminate student food insecurity, Auxiliary Services, Gourmet Dining, and the Office of the Dean of Students began investigating the implementation of a meal plan donation program. The goal also included getting the program recognized by the National Swipe Out Hunger network and establishing an ongoing collaboration with them. In January 2020, Montclair State became an official  Swipe Out Hunger Organization  campus partner. The university has once again teamed up with our resident dining provider, Gourmet Dining, to continue with The Swipe Out Hunger program encompassing both campuses, Montclair and Bloomfield, this semester. 
 Every Montclair State University or Bloomfield College student who is enrolled in a block meal plan (excluding unlimited meal plan holders) will be able to designate up to two (2) swipes per semester to the meal donation program. This drive will be active from October 20 until November 22. No additional meal swipes will be accepted after this date for the Fall 2025 semester.  Fill out this form  to make a difference!

title: Educated Citizenry/Critical Information Literacy Faculty Workshop & Discussion
description:
In this workshop and discussion co-sponsored by the SEEDS Advisory Board and University Libraries, faculty and librarians will share with each other how they define, teach, and assess educated citizenry, information literacy, and critical information literacy.  We will discuss the Educated Citizenry / Critical Information Literacy (CIL)  rubric ; classroom activities that foster student engagement; and ideas for assessing the Educated Citizenry/CIL SEEDS Value. 
 Faculty teaching a course that addresses the Educated Citizenry (Critical Information Literacy) SEEDS Value - or teaching a SEEDS Foundations or Explorations course that includes (critical) information literacy skills as part of its Student Learning Outcomes - are encouraged to participate.  Please bring your laptop, as well as syllabus and assignments/activities for your SEEDS course(s).  
 Light refreshments will be provided. 
 
 Related LibGuide:  Educated Citizenry (Critical Information Literacy) by Bonnie Fong 
 Register Here: https://montclair.libcal.com/event/15397318

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Audiology (AuD) Virtual Information Session
description:
Our  Audiology program  is designed to empower you to excel in multiple roles—clinician, educator, administrator, and researcher. 
 
 As a clinician, you'll be able to identify the hearing health needs of individuals and design, implement and evaluate treatment plans to meet those needs.  
 In education, you'll be equipped to share your knowledge and inspire others in community healthcare settings. 
 As an administrator, you'll learn to lead, innovate, and elevate audiology services across diverse environments. 
 And with a strong foundation in research, you'll be ready to explore new frontiers in audiology, applying cutting-edge insights directly to your practice. 
 
 Join us for a virtual information session November 25 at 7:00 PM (EST)  to become a versatile leader in the dynamic field of audiology, where your impact can resonate for a lifetime.

 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: E PLURIBUS UNUM
description:
The Latin phrase “E pluribus unum” (Out of many, one) is the motto on the Great Seal of the United States. Originally representing the unity of the thirteen colonies forming a single nation, the phrase expanded to encapsulate the idea that we can be a single people with varied backgrounds and histories. In both ways, this motto has often been more aspiration than description. 
 In this final lecture, President Koppell explores what makes us one nation. Is it simply a legal definition, a shared heritage or commitment to a set of ideals? How do we function as a unified nation when the framers fractured power purposely? What are the features of the U.S. that have bonded communities and institutions together in the face of divisive forces? 
 Event is open to all

title: Resumes for Student Business Owners
organization: Feliciano Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation
description:
Running a business while in school? Learn how to make it work FOR you on your resume. 
 Whether you've launched a startup, built a side hustle, or freelanced your way through college, you've gained real-world skills that employers and grad schools are looking for—you just need to know how to showcase them. 
 In this hands-on in-person workshop, you'll learn to: 
 
 Turn your entrepreneurial experience into resume gold 
 Quantify your wins  
 Frame your business skills in ways that make recruiters actually pay attention 
 Avoid common pitfalls that make student entrepreneurs' resumes get overlooked 
 
 Stop underselling your hustle. Walk out with a resume that shows you're not just another candidate—you're someone who makes things happen.

title: Kichwa Language and Culture Workshop Series - 2nd Edition
organization: Center for Latino Heritage & Spanish Language Excellence
description:
After a very successful first edition of our Kichwa Language and Culture classes last spring, we are thrilled to launch a new workshop series starting September 15. This year’s program continues to pair Kichwa language learning with rich cultural experiences: and we’re adding something special. Students will have the opportunity to engage with an acclaimed Indigenous artist, exploring their paintings, the deep connection to nature behind their work, the meaning of colors and subjects, and more. 
 
 Space is limited.  
 Class is starting on Monday, September 15th, every Monday from 5:30pm-7:30pm for the duration of 10 weeks.

title: First Gen Drop-In Group
description:
This is a support drop-in group for first generation college students aimed to help ensure that first-gen students are empowered and prepared to reach their full social, professional, and academic potential. Students will have opportunities to build community, empower and support one another through shared experiences with topics that may include, but not limited to, lack of knowledge about college experience/resources, imposter syndrome, financial and family stress, academic struggles and other challenging subject matters. 
 Group Meets: 
 
 First group will be held on September 9, 2025 
 On Tuesdays from 11:30am – 12:30pm in the Health Promotion Drop-In Center 
 
 For more information, contact group leaders Ms. Charisma Jackson, LCSW at  jacksoncha@montclair.edu

title: 2026 Class Gift Tabling - Information and Philanthropy Cord Pick-Up
description:
Each year, our graduating class participates in a proud Class Gift tradition where members of the class invest in the University by supporting areas of Montclair State University that are most important to them. We invite the Class of 2026 to come together to show your support! 
 All gifts to Montclair count! Make your gift to any area of campus you feel most passionate about – such as the Emergency Book Fund, The Red Hawk Pantry, your school or college, The Fund for Montclair State or athletic program. 
 Your gift will pay it forward for future Red Hawks and kick-start your philanthropic connection to Montclair. 
 
 Commemorate your class year! Make a gift of at least  $20.26  and you’ll receive your customized philanthropy cord to wear over your commencement robe.  
 For a gift of  $40 , celebrate this milestone with your family, friends and colleagues by having your message displayed on the screen at the Commencement you will be participating in, and receive a customized philanthropy cord. 
 
 How do I get my customized philanthropy cord? 
 Customized philanthropy cords will be available for pick-up: 
 
 Tuesday, October 28 from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Thursday, November 20  from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Tuesday, December 2 from 12:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Bloomfield Campus Graduation Fair: Wednesday, December 10th from 12:00 – 6:00 p.m. in Deacon’s Den, Talbott Hall  (for Bloomfield graduates only) 
 Montclair Campus Graduation Fairs: Thursday, December 11th from 10:00 a.m. – 7:00 p.m. in the Student Center Ballrooms  (for Montclair or Bloomfield graduates) 
 
 Graduates can also arrange to pick up their philanthropy cords in the Overlook Corporate Center, 150 Clove Road, Little Falls, NJ during business hours, Monday through Friday, 8:30 a.m. – 4:30 p.m. Philanthropy cords can also be mailed to those who cannot pick it up. The last day we will mail the cords is Monday, December 22, 2025 at 2:30 p.m. Please contact James Stewart, Associate Director of Annual Giving at stewartj@montclair.edu or 973-655-5328 to finalize options to get your cords for the Winter Commencement. 
 Every student has benefitted from donor generosity to areas of academic support, emergency funding for students and overall priorities to boost students’ success every day. Thank you for paying it forward! For more information, please contact James Stewart, Associate Director of Annual Giving, at 973-655-5328 or stewartj@montclair.edu.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Weekly Wednesday Zoom Check-ins @ 8pm
description:
Weekly meetings Description @ 8pm on Wednesdays 
 Welcome to the  ​ Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring   (DREAM)  Group for College Students with  Disabilities and Allies!  We invite and welcome you, (undergraduates, grad students and allies) to a supportive discussion with peers. Whether you would like to just come hang out with us, meet each other, talk about your experiences as students, vent about life or chill and laugh, we can do it all! We can provide each other with community care!  
 If you are coming as an Ally here are a few ways to be an ally to the disabled community: 1) Check your own internalized ableism. 2) Understand that not every disability is visible to you. 3) If you notice inaccessibility, speak up! Advocate for us. 4) Attend events that center disabled voices. 5) If a person in your life has a disability, take the time to learn about it. 6) Make mistakes, apologize, and learn from them. 7) Consume some media (made by disabled people) about disability. 
 Meetings will be held online via Zoom

title: Fireside Chats
description:
Hang out and have casual conversations about anything and everything with other students while enjoying refreshments! Join us on Thursdays from 3:15-4:15pm.  
 What are Fireside Chats: 
 
 A space for students to meet, connect, and have a casual conversation about a given topic, or anything else that feels comfortable for everyone else. It can be about the school climate, student life in general, or your favorite show. All students are welcome!

title: Information Session: Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group
description:
Are you a graduate student working on a journal article for publication? Learn more about the Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group! This writing group will run over 13 weeks during the Spring semester (January 26 - April 24, 2026), with a week off in March. Weekly topics will include: publication venues, selecting a journal, writing your argument, literature review, citation management and more. We will use Wendy Laura Belcher’s  Writing  Your Journal Article in Twelve Weeks  to guide the discussions and work. Register to attend this Zoom information session where we will discuss how the program will run, the expected time commitment, and answer any other questions you may have. Please contact our Graduate Assistant, Emily Cepin, at  cepine1@montclair.edu  with any questions. A limited number of seats are available. If you would like to register for the club without attending an info session, you may do so by completing this  registration form . Sponsored by the Center for Writing Excellence and the University Libraries. 
 Register Here: https://montclair.libcal.com/event/14826432
